 Some fair-minded members of this forum might agree that anyone attempting an unsophisticated defense of a conservative point of view, is quite likely to attract a queue of liberal commentators waiting in line to ridicule and plaster in ordure the unfortunate oaf who sticks his neck out.
 
 However, I'm going to put my head above the parapet for a while and claim that there is something to be said in favour of political conservatism. I'll begin by saying that what attracts me to conservatism is its pragmatism and its skepticism. This political outlook obviously springs from a desire to conserve existing things as either being good in themselves, or better than the likely alternatives. What's more, I want to argue that conservative politics is not based upon and does not seek to propagate a coherent set of principles and dogmas. Conservative opinion emerges from a personal disposition or an attitude towards change and innovation; therefore conservatism has no social program which might bring about a "better society". I'm not sure I could dignify what I'm talking about as a "political philosophy" - it's a response to what is, and not to what might be.
